explanation:
OS_ObjectIdDefined: The for-loop body calls this function; MISRA requires that the behaviour of called functions be included when judging whether the loop body modifies objects used in the loop clauses (or has persistent side-effects). We must inspect OS_ObjectIdDefined (and its callees) to ensure it has no side-effects that modify the loop counter i or the object used in the second clause (max_id) or any other object that would make the second/third clause noncompliant.

OS_common_table: The loop indexes into this global array (obj = &OS_common_table[local_id + base_id]). Reading or writing this table, or functions that access it, could produce side-effects that affect objects used by the loop clauses. We need the declaration/definition to confirm indexing has no hidden side-effects and to see whether accesses could modify other objects used in the for-clause.

OS_common_record_t: The loop dereferences an element of OS_common_table and reads its active_id (obj->active_id) which is passed to OS_ObjectIdDefined. The structure definition is required to know the type of active_id (value vs pointer), and whether accessing it might invoke side-effects (e.g. via volatile members or complex semantics), and to confirm that active_id is not an alias to the loop counter or to max_id.

OS_OBJECT_INDEX_MASK: The loop body uses this macro/constant to test/adjust serial. To reason about whether the loop body modifies any object used in the for-clauses (or has persistent side-effects), the value and nature of this macro must be known (constant vs modifiable), and to ensure its use does not violate the restrictions on expressions in the loop clauses.
